review_title: Recording Arts Programme at Flashpoint Chicago
job_title: Associate Sound Designer in Chicago, IL

review_title: Great bosses and co-workers, great students, not-so-great leadership
pros:
- My coworkers and bosses were wonderful people and very supportive
- I was new to teaching; my hiring manager took a chance on me and helped me thrive
- Managers were very flexible and gave me a ton of freedom to create my curriculum
- I truly enjoyed my job and found it deeply meaningful
cons:
I couldn't shake the looming suspicion that leadership was turning the place into a diploma mill. I experienced so much responsibility creep that I had to cut serious corners with assignments to manage it all, which wasn't fair to me and even less fair to the students. I often had to choose between giving the students the time and attention they deserved and setting professional boundaries to prevent burnout. In the end, burnout won.

- Low pay, no benefits, pay and workload change every few months
- Little opportunity for upward growth
- My department was very under-resourced
-Personnel shake-ups
-Serious lack of tact on leadership's part--who fires a department head and announces a department-wide paycut in the middle of finals week?

review_title: Decline since merging with Columbia College Hollywood
pros: Great students. Fun classroom. Colleagues are a fun community.
cons: Tons of financial issues since the merger with CCH. Weird belt-tightening and random firings to save some $.

review_title: On its last leg. (Despite others saying otherwise)
pros: Full Time Faculty (what remains) are talented and caring.
cons: Panders/takes advantage of low level students, owned by Sterling who has done a terrible reform on the school. Horrible treatment of faculty. Low moral remains of what was once a thriving school.

pros: I loved the students, loved my co-workers, and loved the freedom I had to build my own curriculum. I generally felt respected and supported, and found the work very rewarding.
cons: CCH management made some decisions that made the job unsustainable--the responsibility kept piling on, class sizes swelled, and finally, pay for my role was cut by 20%.
